Tech tool offers police ‘mass surveillance on a budget’Associated Press8/1/2022

Local law enforcement agencies from suburban Southern California to rural North Carolina have been using an obscure cellphone tracking tool, at times without search warrants, that gives them the power to follow people’s movements months back in time, according to public records and internal emails obtained by The Associated Press.

AP Investigations, Technology, U.S. News, Police, California, Arkansas, North Carolina, Government surveillance, Virginia, Law enforcement agencies, Suburbs, Criminal investigations, Congress, Business, Government and politics, AP Top NewsRead

allowfullscreen=""></iframe></div></div><div class="copy-0-2-66 copy-2-0-2-80"><h1 class="headline-0-2-69">Tech tool offers police ‘mass surveillance on a budget’</h1><div class="ssr-desktop"><div class="description-0-2-71"></div><div class="apline-0-2-72"></div></div><div class="ssr-tablet"><div class="description-0-2-71"></div><div class="apline-0-2-72"></div></div></div></div><div class="ssr-mobile"><div class="description-0-2-71"></div><div class="apline-0-2-72"></div></div><div class="reporterContainer-0-2-75 info-0-2-61"><div class="root-0-2-90"><div class="image-0-2-95"></div><div class="name-0-2-92">Garance Burke</div><div class="bio-0-2-93">Garance is a global investigative journalist.</div><a class="link-0-2-94" target="_blank" href="https://twitter.com/garanceburke">garanceburke</a><a class="link-0-2-94" href="mailto:gburke@ap.org">gburke@ap.org</a></div><div class="root-0-2-90"><div class="image-0-2-95"></div><div class="name-0-2-92">Jason Dearen</div><div class="bio-0-2-93">Jason is a national investigative reporter.</div><a class="link-0-2-94" target="_blank" href="https://twitter.com/JHDearen">JHDearen</a><a class="link-0-2-94" href="mailto:jdearen@ap.org">jdearen@ap.org</a></div></div><div class="info-0-2-61"><div class="byline-0-2-63">By GARANCE BURKE and JASON DEAREN</div><span class="Timestamp Component-root-0-2-98 timestamp-0-2-64" data-key="timestamp" data-source="2022-09-01T16:29:05Z" title="2022-09-01 16:29:05 - Thu Sep 01 2022 16:29:05 GMT+0000 (Coordinated Universal Time)">September 1, 2022 GMT</span><div class="socials-0-2-65 socials-1-0-2-79"><a href="https://facebook.com/dialog/share?app_id=870613919693099&display=popup&href=https://apnews.com/article/technology-police-government-surveillance-d395409ef5a8c6c3f6cdab5b1d0e27ef" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" class="Component-root-0-2-99"><svg class="SvgSprite"><use xlink:href="/dist/spritemap.svg#sprite-share-facebook"></use></svg></a><a href="https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?url=https://apnews.com/article/technology-police-government-surveillance-d395409ef5a8c6c3f6cdab5b1d0e27ef" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" class="Component-root-0-2-100"><svg class="SvgSprite"><use xlink:href="/dist/spritemap.svg#sprite-share-twitter"></use></svg></a><a href="mailto:?subject=Tech tool offers police ‘mass surveillance on a budget’&body=https://apnews.com/article/technology-police-government-surveillance-d395409ef5a8c6c3f6cdab5b1d0e27ef" class="Component-root-0-2-101"><svg class="SvgSprite"><use xlink:href="/dist/spritemap.svg#sprite-share-email"></use></svg></a><div class="Component-root-0-2-102"><textarea tabindex="-1" class="Component-area-0-2-105">https://apnews.com/article/technology-police-government-surveillance-d395409ef5a8c6c3f6cdab5b1d0e27ef</textarea><svg class="SvgSprite"><use xlink:href="/dist/spritemap.svg#sprite-share-link-small"></use></svg></div></div></div><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">Local law enforcement agencies from suburban Southern California to rural North Carolina have been using an obscure cellphone tracking tool, at times without search warrants, that gives them the power to follow people’s movements months back in time, according to public records and internal emails obtained by The Associated Press.</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">Police have used “Fog Reveal” to search hundreds of billions of records from 250 million mobile devices, and harnessed the data to create location analyses known among law enforcement as “patterns of life,” according to thousands of pages of records about the company.</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">Sold by Virginia-based Fog Data Science LLC, Fog Reveal has been used since at least 2018 in criminal investigations ranging from the murder of a nurse in Arkansas to tracing the movements of a potential participant in the Jan. 6 insurrection at the Capitol. The tool is rarely, if ever, mentioned in court records, something that defense attorneys say makes it harder for them to properly defend their clients in cases in which the technology was used.</p><div class="image-0-2-50 alignLeft-0-2-51 wrapper-0-2-107" data-key="media-placeholder"></div><div class="image-0-2-50 alignRight-0-2-52 wrapper-0-2-107" data-key="media-placeholder"></div><div class="forceBreak-0-2-73"></div><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">The company was developed by two former high-ranking Department of Homeland Security officials under former President George W. Bush. It relies on advertising identification numbers, which Fog officials say are culled from popular cellphone apps such as Waze, Starbucks and hundreds of others that target ads based on a person’s movements and interests, according to police emails. That information is then sold to companies like Fog.</p><div class="dfp-0-2-55 apnews_article_midarticle_1"><div class="Component-adTitle-0-2-116">ADVERTISEMENT</div><div class="Component-placeholderWrapper-0-2-119"><div class="Component-visualPlaceholder-0-2-117"></div></div></div><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">“It’s sort of a mass surveillance program on a budget,” said Bennett Cyphers, a special adviser at the Electronic Frontier Foundation, a digital privacy rights advocacy group.</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">_____</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">This story, supported by the Pulitzer Center for Crisis Reporting, is part of an ongoing Associated Press series, “Tracked,” that investigates the power and consequences of decisions driven by algorithms on people’s everyday lives.</p><div class="image-0-2-50 wrapper-0-2-107" data-key="media-placeholder"></div><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">____</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">The documents and emails were obtained by EFF through Freedom of Information Act requests. The group shared the files with The AP, which independently found that Fog sold its software in about 40 contracts to nearly two dozen agencies, according to GovSpend, a company that keeps tabs on government spending. The records and AP’s reporting provide the first public account of the extensive use of Fog Reveal by local police, according to analysts and legal experts who scrutinize such technologies.</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">Federal oversight of companies like Fog is an evolving legal landscape. On Monday, the Federal Trade Commission sued a data broker called Kochava that, like Fog, provides its clients with advertising IDs that authorities say can easily be used to find where a mobile device user lives, which violates rules the commission enforces. And there are bills before Congress now that, if passed, would regulate the industry.</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">“Local law enforcement is at the front lines of trafficking and missing persons cases, yet these departments are often behind in technology adoption,” Matthew Broderick, a Fog managing partner, said in an email. “We fill a gap for underfunded and understaffed departments.”</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">Because of the secrecy surrounding Fog, however, there are scant details about its use and most law enforcement agencies won’t discuss it, raising concerns among privacy advocates that it violates the <a href="https://www.uscourts.gov/about-federal-courts/educational-resources/about-educational-outreach/activity-resources/what-does-0#:~:text=The%20Constitution%2C%20through%20the%20Fourth,deemed%20unreasonable%20under%20the%20law." target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" class="paragraph-link">Fourth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution</a><!-- -->, which protects against unreasonable search and seizure.</p><div class="image-0-2-50 alignFull-0-2-53 wrapper-0-2-107" data-key="media-placeholder"></div><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">What distinguishes Fog Reveal from other cellphone location technologies used by police is that it follows the devices through their advertising IDs, unique numbers assigned to each device. These numbers do not contain the name of the phone’s user, but can be traced to homes and workplaces to help police establish pattern-of-life analyses.</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">“The capability that it had for bringing up just anybody in an area whether they were in public or at home seemed to me to be a very clear violation of the Fourth Amendment,” said Davin Hall, a former crime data analysis supervisor for the Greensboro, North Carolina, Police Department. “I just feel angry and betrayed and lied to.”</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">Hall resigned in late 2020 after months of voicing concerns about the department’s use of Fog to police attorneys and the city council. </p><div class="image-0-2-50 wrapper-0-2-107" data-key="media-placeholder"></div><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">While Greensboro officials acknowledged Fog’s use and initially defended it, the police department said it allowed its subscription to expire earlier this year because it didn’t “independently benefit investigations.”</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">But federal, state and local police agencies around the U.S. continue to use Fog with very little public accountability. Local police agencies have been enticed by Fog’s affordable price: It can start as low as $7,500 a year. And some departments that license it have shared access with other nearby law enforcement agencies, the emails show.</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">Police departments also like how quickly they can access detailed location information from Fog. Geofence warrants, which tap into GPS and other sources to track a device, are accessed by obtaining such data from companies, like Google or Apple. This requires police to obtain a warrant and ask the tech companies for the specific data they want, which can take days or weeks.</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">Using Fog’s data, which the company claims is anonymized, police can geofence an area or search by a specific device’s ad ID numbers, according to a user agreement obtained by AP. But, Fog maintains that “we have no way of linking signals back to a specific device or owner,” according to a sales representative who emailed the California Highway Patrol in 2018, after a lieutenant asked whether the tool could be legally used.</p><div class="social-embed Component-embed-0-2-81 block-0-2-47" id="se2:effc5ae0-02f0-11ed-8ff5-d3ec7a905745"><div><div class="YoutubeEmbed youtubeEmbed"><div class="vertical-wrapper"><div class="vertical-limit"></div><img alt="ratio" class="ratio" src="data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAABAAAAAJCAAAAAAeQfPuAAAAC0lEQVQYGWMYrAAAAJkAAWzZLOIAAAAASUVORK5CIIA="/></div><div class="horizontal-limit"></div><div class="youtube-player" id="youtube-wrapper-qYfjWUxdkCc-article"><img class="thumbnail" src="" alt="Youtube video thumbnail"/></div></div><p class="social-caption Component-root-0-2-89 Component-caption-0-2-82 caption-0-2-60">You might know that your cellphone has a unique code that allows advertisers to target you for promotions. What you may not know: That same number could be helping police surveil you without a warrant. (AP video: Allen Breed, Haven Daley)</p></div></div><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">Despite such privacy assurances, the records show that law enforcement can use Fog’s data as a clue to find identifying information. “There is no (personal information) linked to the (ad ID),” wrote a Missouri official about Fog in 2019. “But if we are good at what we do, we should be able to figure out the owner.”</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">Fog’s Broderick said in an email that the company does not have access to people’s personal information, and draws from “commercially available data without restrictions to use,” from data brokers “that legitimately purchase data from apps in accordance with their legal agreements.” The company refused to share information about how many police agencies it works with.</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">“We are confident Law Enforcement has the responsible leadership, constraints, and political guidance at the municipal, state, and federal level to ensure that any law enforcement tool and method is appropriately used in accordance with the laws in their respective jurisdictions,” Broderick said.</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">___</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">Kevin Metcalf, a prosecutor in Washington County, Arkansas, said he has used Fog Reveal without a warrant, especially in “exigent circumstances.” In these cases, the law provides a warrant exemption when a crime-in-process endangers people or an officer. </p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">Metcalf also leads the National Child Protection Task Force, a nonprofit that combats child exploitation and trafficking. Fog <a href="https://www.ncptf.org/team" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" class="paragraph-link">is listed on its website</a><!-- --> as a task force sponsor and a company executive chairs the nonprofit’s board. Metcalf said Fog has been invaluable to cracking missing children cases and homicides.</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">“We push the limits, but we do them in a way that we target the bad guys,” he said. “Time is of the essence in those situations. We can’t wait on the traditional search warrant route.”</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">Fog was used successfully in the murder case of 25-year-old nurse Sydney Sutherland, who had last been seen jogging near Newport, Arkansas, before she disappeared, Metcalf said.</p><div class="dfp-0-2-55 apnews_article_midarticle_2"><div class="Component-adTitle-0-2-116">ADVERTISEMENT</div><div class="Component-placeholderWrapper-0-2-119"><div class="Component-visualPlaceholder-0-2-117"></div></div></div><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">Police had little evidence to go on when they found her phone in a ditch, so Metcalf said he shared his agency’s access to Fog with the U.S. Marshals Service to figure out which other devices had been nearby at the time she was killed. He said Fog helped lead authorities to arrest a farmer in Sutherland’s rape and murder in August 2020, but its use was not documented in court records reviewed by AP.</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">Cyphers, who led EFF’s public records work, said there hasn’t been any previous record of companies selling this kind of granular data directly to local law enforcement.</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">“We’re seeing counties with less than 100,000 people where the sheriff is using this extremely high tech, extremely invasive, secretive surveillance tool to chase down local crime,” Cyphers said.</p><div class="image-0-2-50 wrapper-0-2-107" data-key="media-placeholder"></div><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">One such customer is the sheriff’s office in rural Rockingham County, North Carolina, population 91,000 and just north of Greensboro, where Hall still lives. The county bought a one-year license for $9,000 last year and recently renewed it.</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">“Rockingham County is tiny in terms of population. It never ceases to amaze me how small agencies will scoop up tools that they just absolutely don’t need, and nobody needs this one,” Hall said.</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">Sheriff’s spokesman Lt. Kevin Suthard confirmed the department recently renewed its license but declined to offer specifics about the use of Fog Reveal or how the office protects individuals’ rights. </p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">“Because it would then be less effective as criminals could be cognizant that we have the device and adjust their commission of the crimes accordingly. Make sense?” Suthard said.</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">Fog has aggressively marketed its tool to police, even beta testing it with law enforcement, records show. The Dallas Police Department bought a Fog license in February after getting a free trial and “seeing a demonstration and hearing of success stories from the company,” Senior Cpl. Melinda Gutierrez, a department spokeswoman, said in an email.</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">Fog’s tool is accessed through a web portal. Investigators can enter a crime scene’s coordinates into the database, which brings back search results showing a device’s Fog ID, which is based on its unique ad ID number.</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">Police can see which device IDs were found near the location of the crime. Detectives or other officers can also search the location for IDs going forward from the time of the crime and back at least 180 days, according to the company’s user license agreement. But, Fog’s data can go back as far as June 2017, according to emails from a Fog representative to Florida and California law enforcement agencies.</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">While the data does not directly identify who owns a device, the company often gives law enforcement information it needs to connect it to addresses and other clues that help detectives figure out people’s identities, according to company representatives’ emails.</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">It is unclear how Fog makes these connections, but a company it refers to as its “data partner” called Venntel, Inc. has access to an even greater trove of users’ mobile data.</p><div class="image-0-2-50 wrapper-0-2-107" data-key="media-placeholder"></div><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">Venntel is a large broker that has supplied location data to agencies such as Immigration and Customs Enforcement and the FBI. The Department of Homeland Security’s watchdog is currently investigating how U.S. border agents used Venntel data to track people’s locations inside the U.S. without a search warrant. The company also has faced congressional inquiries about privacy concerns tied to federal law enforcement agencies’ use of its data.</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">Venntel and Fog work closely together to aid police detectives during investigations, emails show. Their marketing brochures are nearly identical, too, and Venntel staff has recommended Fog to law enforcement, according to the emails. Venntel said “the confidential nature of our business relationships” prevented it from responding to AP’s specific questions, and Fog would not comment on the relationship.</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">While Fog says in its marketing materials that it collects data from thousands of apps, like Starbucks and Waze, companies are not always aware of who is using their data. Venntel and Fog can collect billions of data points filled with detailed information because many apps embed invisible tracking software that follows users’ behavior. This software also lets the apps sell customized ads that are targeted to a person’s current location. In turn, data brokers’ software can hoover up personal data that can be used for other purposes. Fog did not specifically say how it got the data from Starbucks and Waze.</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">For their part, Starbucks and Waze denied any relationship to Fog. Starbucks said it had not given permission to its business partners to share customer information with Fog.</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">“Starbucks has not approved Ad ID data generated by our app to be used in this way by Fog Data Science LLC. In our review to date, we have no relationship with this company,” said Megan Adams, a Starbucks spokesperson.</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">“We have never had a relationship with Fog Data Science, have not worked with them in any capacity, and have not shared information with them,” a Waze spokesperson said.</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">___</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">Fog Data Science LLC is headquartered in a nondescript brick building in Leesburg, Virginia. It also has related entities in New Jersey, Ohio and Texas.</p><div class="dfp-0-2-55 apnews_article_midarticle_3"><div class="Component-adTitle-0-2-116">ADVERTISEMENT</div><div class="Component-placeholderWrapper-0-2-119"><div class="Component-visualPlaceholder-0-2-117"></div></div></div><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">It was founded in 2016 by Robert Liscouski, who led the Department of Homeland Security’s National Cyber Security Division in the George W. Bush adminstration. His colleague, Broderick, is a former U.S. Marine brigadier general who ran DHS’ tech hub, the Homeland Security Operations Center, during Hurricane Katrina in 2005. A House bipartisan committee report cited Broderick among others for failing to coordinate a swift federal response to the deadly hurricane. Broderick resigned from DHS shortly thereafter.</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">In marketing materials, Fog also has touted its ability to offer police “predictive analytics,” a buzzword often used to describe high-tech policing tools that purport to predict crime hotspots. Liscouski and another Fog official have worked at companies focused on predictive analytics, machine learning and software platforms supporting artificial intelligence.</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">“It is capable of delivering both forensic and predictive analytics and near real-time insights on the daily movements of the people identified with those mobile devices,” reads an email announcing a Fog training last year for members of the National Fusion Center Association, which represents a network of intelligence-sharing partnerships created after the Sept. 11 attacks.</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">Fog’s Broderick said the company had not invested in predictive applications, and provided no details about any uses the tool had for predicting crime.</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">Despite privacy advocates’ concerns about warrantless surveillance, Fog Reveal has caught on with local and state police forces. It’s been used in a number of high-profile criminal cases, including one that was the subject of the television program “48 Hours.”</p><div class="block-0-2-47 HubPeek noBorderBottom-0-2-125 compressedEmbed-0-2-126"><div data-key="feed-card-hub-peak" class="hubPeekContainerWide-0-2-128"><div class="title-0-2-129"><a class="blueTitle-0-2-130 blueTitle-1-0-2-137 overrideArticle" href="/hub/technology"><h3 class="title-0-2-129">Technology</h3></a></div><div class="columnLayout-0-2-134"><li class="listItem-0-2-148"><a class="wireStoryContainer-0-2-139 noImage-0-2-140 hub-peek-story-link" href="/article/biden-technology-new-zealand-games-ac1c3b81267f40f1d2be2406a764c1bf"><div class="imageContainer-0-2-141"></div><div class="titleContainer-0-2-142"><div class="title-0-2-143 overrideArticle"><h4 class="headline-0-2-146 newStandardStyle">Microsoft's Activision Blizzard deal gets global scrutiny</h4></div></div></a></li><li class="listItem-0-2-148"><a class="wireStoryContainer-0-2-139 noImage-0-2-140 hub-peek-story-link" href="/article/technology-china-global-trade-nvidia-corp-5b5f7476a427182229f620ae82ddb939"><div class="imageContainer-0-2-141"></div><div class="titleContainer-0-2-142"><div class="title-0-2-143 overrideArticle"><h4 class="headline-0-2-146 newStandardStyle">China demands US drop tech export curbs after Nvidia warning</h4></div></div></a></li><div class="divider-0-2-132"></div><div class="divider-0-2-132"></div><li class="listItem-0-2-148"><a class="wireStoryContainer-0-2-139 noImage-0-2-140 hub-peek-story-link" href="/article/technology-united-kingdom-187332bc07d6930b18e54010c38b6353"><div class="imageContainer-0-2-141"></div><div class="titleContainer-0-2-142"><div class="title-0-2-143 overrideArticle"><h4 class="headline-0-2-146 newStandardStyle">Microsoft's Activision Blizzard deal faces more UK scrutiny</h4></div></div></a></li><li class="listItem-0-2-148"><a class="wireStoryContainer-0-2-139 noImage-0-2-140 hub-peek-story-link" href="/article/technology-social-media-2f127fdbcb1928ab30008bdb62a48905"><div class="imageContainer-0-2-141"></div><div class="titleContainer-0-2-142"><div class="title-0-2-143 overrideArticle"><h4 class="headline-0-2-146 newStandardStyle">Twitter readies edit feature for premium users</h4></div></div></a></li></div></div></div><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">In 2017, a world-renowned exotic snake breeder was found dead, lying in a pool of blood in his reptile breeding facility in rural Missouri. Police initially thought the breeder, Ben Renick, might have died from a poisonous snake bite. But the evidence soon pointed to murder.</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">During its investigation, emails show the Missouri State Highway Patrol used Fog’s portal to search for cellphones at Renick’s home and breeding facility and zeroed in on a mobile device. Working with Fog, investigators used the data to identify the phone owner’s identity: it was the Renicks’ babysitter.</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">Police were able to log the babysitter’s whereabouts over time to create a pattern of life analysis. </p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">It turned out to be a dead-end lead. Renick’s wife, Lynlee, later was charged and convicted of the murder.</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">Prosecutors did not cite Fog in a list of other tools they used in the investigation, according to trial exhibits examined by the AP. </p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">But Missouri officials seemed pleased with Fog’s capabilities, even though it didn’t directly lead to an arrest. “It was interesting to see that the system did pick up a device that was absolutely in the area that day. Too bad it did not belong to a suspect!” a Missouri State Highway Patrol analyst wrote in an email to Fog.</p><div class="dfp-0-2-55 apnews_article_midarticle_4"><div class="Component-adTitle-0-2-116">ADVERTISEMENT</div><div class="Component-placeholderWrapper-0-2-119"><div class="Component-visualPlaceholder-0-2-117"></div></div></div><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">In another high-profile criminal probe, records show the FBI asked state intelligence officials in Iowa for help with Fog as it investigated potential participants in the events at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6.</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">“Not definitive but still waiting to talk things over with a FOG rep,” wrote Justin Parker, deputy director of the Iowa Department of Public Safety, in an email to an FBI official in September 2021. It was unclear from the emails if Fog’s data factored into an arrest, and neither the FBI nor Iowa officials would comment.</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">___</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">Metcalf, the Arkansas prosecutor, has argued against congressional efforts to require search warrants when using technologies like Fog Reveal.</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">He believes Americans have given up any reasonable expectation of privacy when they use free apps and likens EFF’s objections to tech like Fog to a “cult of privacy.”</p><div class="dfp-0-2-55 apnews_article_midarticle_5"><div class="Component-adTitle-0-2-116">ADVERTISEMENT</div><div class="Component-placeholderWrapper-0-2-119"><div class="Component-visualPlaceholder-0-2-117"></div></div></div><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">“I think people are going to have to make a decision on whether we want all this free technology, we want all this free stuff, we want all the selfies,” he said. “But we can’t have that and at the same time say, ‘I’m a private person, so you can’t look at any of that.’ That just seems crazy.”</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">Although he is not an official Fog employee, Metcalf said he would step in to lead training sessions including the tool for federal prosecutors, federal agencies and police, including the Chicago Police Department, the emails show.</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">That kind of hands-on service and word-of-mouth marketing in tight-knit law enforcement circles seems to have helped increase Fog’s popularity.</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">The Maryland State Police is among the many agencies that have had contracts for Fog Reveal, and records show investigators believed it had a lot of potential.</p><div class="social-embed Component-embed-0-2-81 alignFull-0-2-53" id="se1:70ba9330-02f0-11ed-d109-9f09bc703a39"><div class="Component-root-0-2-86 Component-root-1-0-2-124"><iframe class="Component-player-0-2-87" src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/744726603?background=1" allow="autoplay; fullscreen" title="Vimeo video" allowfullscreen=""></iframe></div><p class="social-caption Component-root-0-2-89 Component-caption-0-2-82 caption-0-2-60">A cell phone tower in Raleigh, North Carolina</p></div><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">“Companies have receptors all over. Malls, shopping centers, etc. They’re all around you,” wrote Sgt. John Bedell of the Criminal Enforcement Division, in an email to a colleague. The agency purchased a year of access to Fog in 2018.</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">“Picture getting a suspect’s phone then in the extraction being able to see everyplace they’d been in the last 18 months plotted on a map you filter by date ranges,” wrote Bedell. “The success lies in the secrecy.” </p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">Elena Russo, a spokesperson for the agency, confirmed it had a Fog license previously but that it had lapsed. “Unfortunately, it was not helpful in solving any crimes,” she wrote in an email.</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">Still, as more local policing agencies sign up for Fog, some elected officials said they have been left in the dark. Several officials said there wasn’t enough information to grasp what services Fog actually provides.</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">“Who is this company? What are the track records? What are the privacy protections?” asked Anaheim council member Jose Moreno, remembering his confusion about Fog during a 2020 council meeting. “That night our chief had very little information for us.”</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">In Anaheim, the Fog license was paid for by a federal “Urban Area Security Initiative,” DHS grants that help localities fund efforts to prevent terrorism. A police spokesman said the department has not used it. </p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">Defense attorneys worry there are few legal restrictions on law enforcement’s use of location data.</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">It’s a gap police agencies exploit, and often don’t disclose in court, said Michael Price, litigation director of the National Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers’ Fourth Amendment Center.</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">“(Fog) is exceedingly rare to see in the wild because the cops often don’t get warrants,” said Price.</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">“Even if you do ask for (information) sometimes they say ‘We don’t know what you are talking about.’”</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">Privacy advocates worry Fog’s location tracking could be put to other novel uses, like keeping tabs on people who seek abortions in states where it is now illegal. These concerns were heightened when <a class="paragraph-link" href="/article/abortion-health-nebraska-government-and-politics-b94abeeed9a8c486cf479d6ae78c62aa">a Nebraska woman was charged in August</a><!-- --> with helping her teenage daughter end a pregnancy after investigators got hold of their Facebook messages.</p><div class="image-0-2-50 alignFull-0-2-53 wrapper-0-2-107" data-key="media-placeholder"></div><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">Government’s use of location data is still being weighed by the courts, too. In 2018, the Supreme Court ruled that police generally need a warrant to look at records that reveal where cellphone users have been.</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">Nearly two years after walking off the crime data supervisor job with the Greensboro police force, Hall still worries about police surveillance in neighboring communities.</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">“Anyone with that login information can do as many searches as they want,” Hall said. “I don’t believe the police have earned the trust to use that, and I don’t believe it should be legal.”</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">___</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">AP National Writer Allen G. Breed contributed from Greensboro, North Carolina. Dearen reported from New York and Burke reported from San Francisco.</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">___</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">This reporting was produced in collaboration with researchers Janine Graham, Nicole Waddick and Jane Yang as well as the University of California, Berkeley’s Human Rights Center Investigations Lab and School of Law.</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">___</p><p class="Component-root-0-2-106 paragraph-0-2-48">Follow Garance Burke and Jason Dearen on Twitter at <a href="https://twitter.com/garanceburke" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" class="paragraph-link">@garanceburke</a><!-- --> and <a href="https://twitter.com/jhdearen" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" class="paragraph-link">@jhdearen</a><!-- -->. plan to buy video game giant Activision Blizzard for $68.7 billion could have major effects on the gaming industry, transforming the Xbox maker into something like a Netflix for video g...","isTpContent":false,"socialEmbeds":[],"isPrContent":false,"storyHTML":"\u003cp>Microsoft’s \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/microsoft-activision-blizzard-acquisition-call-of-duty-7a9e2bcc8f0b7b9049e4f93fe3e0a4dd\">plan to buy video game giant Activision Blizzard\u003c/a> for $68.7 billion could have major effects on the gaming industry, transforming the Xbox maker into something like a Netflix for video games by giving it control of many more popular titles.\u003c/p>\u003cp>But to get to the next level, Microsoft must first survive a barrage of government inquiries from New Zealand to Brazil, and from U.S. regulators emboldened by President Joe Biden to strengthen their enforcement of antitrust laws. \u003c/p>\u003cp>More than seven months after Microsoft announced the deal, only \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/Saudigac_en/status/1561586394182651909/photo/1\">Saudi Arabia has announced its approval.\u003c/a> In the United Kingdom, regulators on Thursday \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/technology-united-kingdom-187332bc07d6930b18e54010c38b6353\">threatened to escalate their investigation\u003c/a> unless both companies come up with proposals within five days to ease competition concerns. \u003c/p>\u003cp>“A growing number of countries are subjecting major global transactions to deeper scrutiny,” said William Kovacic, a former chairman of the five-member U.S. Federal Trade Commission. “Many of the jurisdictions that are exercising that scrutiny are significant economies and can’t be brushed off.”\u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"ad-placeholder\" data='autoembed'>\u003c/div>\u003cp>Microsoft has faced antitrust scrutiny before, mostly notably more than two decades ago when a federal judge ordered its breakup following the company’s anticompetitive actions related to its dominant Windows software. That verdict was overturned on appeal, although the court imposed other, less drastic, penalties on the company.\u003c/p>\u003cdiv id='afs:Card:619840132096' class='hub-peek-embed' content-id='ac1c3b81267f40f1d2be2406a764c1bf'>Hub peek embed (JoeBiden) - Compressed layout (automatic embed) \u003c/div>\u003cp>In recent years, however, Microsoft has largely escaped the more intense regulatory backlash its Big Tech rivals such as Amazon, Google and Facebook’s parent company Meta have endured. But the sheer size of the Activision Blizzard merger has drawn global attention.\u003c/p>\u003cp>The all-cash deal is set to be the largest in the history of the tech industry. It would give Microsoft, maker of the Xbox console and gaming system, control of popular game franchises such as Call of Duty, World of Warcraft and Candy Crush. There's also a growing sense that past review of Big Tech mergers was too lax — such as when Facebook bought Instagram in 2012 and WhatsApp in 2014. \u003c/p>\u003cp>“Collectively, that means that the kinds of concessions you’re going to have to make become more difficult,” Kovacic said.\u003c/p>\u003cp>The possibility of Microsoft gaining control of Call of Duty has been particularly worrisome to Sony, maker of the PlayStation console that competes with Microsoft's Xbox. In a letter to Brazilian regulators, Sony emphasized Call of Duty as an “essential” game — a blockbuster so popular and ingrained that it would be impossible for a competitor to develop a rival product even if they had the budget to do so.\u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"ad-placeholder\" data='autoembed'>\u003c/div>\u003cp>The \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/technology-united-kingdom-0e19c4494d1754dc12e23bbf9e68d090\">U.K. watchdog's preliminary inquiry\u003c/a> raised similar worries. It said Microsoft’s control of popular Activision Blizzard games raised concerns that the deal would hurt rivals in multi-game subscription services and the cloud gaming market. \u003c/p>\u003cp>One solution could be a settlement in which Microsoft agrees to ensure that console-making rivals such as Sony or Nintendo won’t be cut off from popular Activision Blizzard games. Microsoft has already publicly signaled its openness to that concept.\u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"ad-placeholder\" data='autoembed'>\u003c/div>\u003cp>Microsoft’s president, Brad Smith, has said the company committed to Sony to make Activision games like Call of Duty “available on PlayStation beyond the existing agreement and into the future” -- although many are skeptical about how long those promises would last if not set into regulatory consent decrees.\u003c/p>\u003cp>On the other hand, Microsoft also has a much better reputation in Washington than it did in 2000. It is \"seen as more reasonable and sensible” on issues such as data privacy, Kovacic said.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Microsoft has also been working to win over skeptics in the U.S., starting with a labor union that's been trying to organize Activision Blizzard employees. Democratic lawmakers have also expressed concern about allegations of Activision's toxic workplace culture for women, which led to employee walkouts last year as well as discrimination lawsuits brought by California and federal civil rights enforcers.\u003c/p>\u003cp>In March, the Communications Workers of America had issued a call seeking tougher oversight of the deal from the U.S. Department of Justice, the FTC and state attorneys general. But a June 30 letter from the union to the FTC said it had switched to supporting the deal after Microsoft agreed “to ensure the workers of Activision Blizzard have a clear path to collective bargaining.”\u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"ad-placeholder\" data='autoembed'>\u003c/div>\u003cp>Gaming represents a growing portion of Microsoft’s business, despite the company’s efforts to portray itself and Activision Blizzard as “small players in a highly fragmented publishing space,” per a document \u003ca href=\"https://comcom.govt.nz/case-register/case-register-entries/microsoft-corporation-activision-blizzard-inc\">filed with New Zealand's Commerce Commission\u003c/a>. \u003c/p>\u003cp>In 2021, Microsoft spent $7.5 billion to acquire ZeniMax Media, the parent company of video game publisher Bethesda Softworks, which is behind popular video games The Elder Scrolls, Doom and Fallout. Microsoft’s properties also include the hit game Minecraft after it bought Swedish game studio Mojang for $2.5 billion in 2014.\u003c/p>\u003cp>The Redmond, Washington, tech giant has said the gaming acquisitions will help beef up its Xbox Game Pass game subscription service and its mobile offerings, particularly from Activision Blizzard's King division, which makes Candy Crush.\u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"ad-placeholder\" data='autoembed'>\u003c/div>\u003cp>Dutch game developer Rami Ismail said Microsoft’s subscription-based service has thus far been a positive for smaller game studios trying to get their content to users. But he’s unsure about the long-term impact of the merger.\u003c/p>\u003cp>“Xbox Game Pass as a product has been really good in getting interesting, creative games funded that might not have the normal market reach to be successful,” Ismail said. “On the flip side, as power consolidates, there is less of an incentive to do anything like that.”\u003c/p>\u003cp>Microsoft rivals are also consolidating. Sony in July closed on a $3.6 billion deal to buy Bungie Inc., maker of the popular game franchise Destiny and the original developer of Xbox-owned Halo. Take-Two Interactive, maker of Grand Theft Auto and Red Dead Redemption, in May completed a $12.7 billion deal to acquire mobile gaming company Zynga, maker of FarmVille and Words With Friends.\u003c/p>","alertLinkDateTime":null,"storyLayout":{},"reporters":[],"headlinePlacement":null,"relatedStoryEmbeds":[],"disableNativo":false}],"disclaimerText":null,"dividerColor":null,"expandedStoryCount":null,"feed":[],"headlineWidget":false,"hubPeekLinkText":null,"hubPeekTagId":null,"hubPeekTagName":null,"hubPeekCanonicalName":null,"hubPeekIsPr":null,"minimizedStoryCount":null,"tagObjs":[{"id":"JoeBiden","name":"Joe some...","isTpContent":false,"socialEmbeds":[],"isPrContent":false,"storyHTML":"\u003cp>BEIJING (AP) — The Chinese government on Thursday called on Washington to repeal its technology export curbs after California-based chip designer Nvidia said a new product might be delayed and some work might be moved out of China.\u003c/p>\u003cp>The latest controls add to mounting U.S.-Chinese tension over technology and security. American officials say they need to limit the spread of technology that can be used to make weapons.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Nvidia said it was told last week it needs a U.S. government license to export any product with performance equal to its A100 graphics processing chips or better to China, Hong Kong or Russia. It said buyers of the A100, and development of the newer H100, might be affected.\u003c/p>\u003cp>But in an amended disclosure Thursday to U.S. securities regulators, the company said the U.S. government was offering some reprieve by authorizing certain chip exports that will enable Nvidia to keep supplying them to American customers through March.\u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"ad-placeholder\" data='autoembed'>\u003c/div>\u003cp>The high-end chips are designed to help power data centers and run artificial intelligence applications. The restrictions don't affect Nvidia's better-known products used in video games and automotive technology.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Another U.S. chipmaker affected by the rules, Advanced Micro Devices, didn't immediately return requests for comment Thursday.\u003c/p>\u003cdiv id='afs:Card:197563501016' class='hub-peek-embed' content-id='5b5f7476a427182229f620ae82ddb939'>Hub peek embed (apf-technology) - Compressed layout (automatic embed) \u003c/div>\u003cp>China's Commerce Ministry accused Washington of abusing export controls to limit semiconductor sales to China. It said trade curbs would disrupt supply chains and global economic recovery.\u003c/p>\u003cp>“China firmly opposes this,” said a ministry spokesperson, Shu Jueting. “The U.S. side should immediately stop its erroneous practices, treat companies from all countries equally, including from China, and do more to contribute to world economic stability.”\u003c/p>\u003cp>U.S. officials increasingly worry about Chinese technology development as both a strategic threat and a potential challenge to American industrial leadership.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Washington has tightened controls and lobbied allies to limit Chinese access to the most advanced chips and tools to develop its own. China is spending heavily to develop its fledgling producers but cannot make high-end chips used in the most advanced smartphones and other devices.\u003c/p>\u003cp>In a earlier disclosure Wednesday, Nvidia said it may be required to “transition certain operations out of China.” The company said it was asking the U.S. government for exemptions for its development and support activities.\u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"ad-placeholder\" data='autoembed'>\u003c/div>\u003cp>It said it would try to meet Chinese customer needs with products that aren’t subject to license requirements. It said the company may seek a license for customers that need them but “has no assurance” the U.S. government will agree.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Shares in Nvidia Corp., which is based in Santa Clara, California, were down 11% on Thursday.\u003c/p>","alertLinkDateTime":null,"storyLayout":{},"reporters":[],"headlinePlacement":null,"relatedStoryEmbeds":[],"disableNativo":false}],"disclaimerText":null,"dividerColor":null,"expandedStoryCount":null,"feed":[],"headlineWidget":false,"hubPeekLinkText":null,"hubPeekTagId":null,"hubPeekTagName":null,"hubPeekCanonicalName":null,"hubPeekIsPr":null,"minimizedStoryCount":null,"tagObjs":[{"id":"apf-technology","name":"Technology","canonicalName":"technology","isPr":false},{"id":"apf-asiapac","name":"Asia c...","isTpContent":false,"socialEmbeds":[],"isPrContent":false,"storyHTML":"\u003cp>LONDON (AP) — Microsoft’s plan to buy video game company Activision Blizzard faced a potential setback Thursday after British antitrust regulators demanded concessions from both companies to ease competition concerns about the blockbuster deal.\u003c/p>\u003cp>The Competition and Markets Authority said it was worried the $69 billion deal would hurt rivals by restricting their access to Activision Blizzard games. It also worried that the combined company would stifle competition in the emerging cloud gaming market. \u003c/p>\u003cp>The authority gave both companies five days to come up with proposals to address its concerns, otherwise it would escalate its investigation with more scrutiny. \u003c/p>\u003cp>The all-cash deal is set to be the largest in the history of the tech industry. It would give Microsoft, maker of the Xbox console and gaming system, control of popular game franchises such as Call of Duty, World of Warcraft and Candy Crush. \u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"ad-placeholder\" data='autoembed'>\u003c/div>\u003cp>The watchdog had \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/technology-united-kingdom-0e19c4494d1754dc12e23bbf9e68d090\">opened an initial inquiry in July\u003c/a> to assess whether the deal would result in a “substantial lessening of competition” in the United Kingdom. \u003c/p>\u003cp>“Following our Phase 1 investigation, we are concerned that Microsoft could use its control over popular games like Call of Duty and World of Warcraft post-merger to harm rivals, including recent and future rivals in multi-game subscription services and cloud gaming,\" the watchdog's senior director of mergers, Sorcha O’Carroll, said in press statement. \u003c/p>\u003cdiv id='afs:Card:197563501016' class='hub-peek-embed' content-id='187332bc07d6930b18e54010c38b6353'>Hub peek embed (apf-technology) - Compressed layout (automatic embed) \u003c/div>\u003cp>Microsoft President Brad Smith said the company is “ready to work with the CMA on next steps and address any of its concerns.” \u003c/p>\u003cp>\u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/biden-technology-new-zealand-games-ac1c3b81267f40f1d2be2406a764c1bf\">Competition regulators around the world\u003c/a> are subjecting the transaction, \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/microsoft-activision-blizzard-acquisition-call-of-duty-7a9e2bcc8f0b7b9049e4f93fe3e0a4dd\">which was announced in January\u003c/a>, to a barrage of scrutiny. So far only Saudi Arabia has given approval for the deal. \u003c/p>\u003cp>Watchdogs from New Zealand to Brazil are still examining the purchase, as are U.S. regulators emboldened by President Joe Biden to strengthen their enforcement of antitrust laws. \u003c/p>\u003cp>The stepped-up scrutiny comes amid a growing sense that past reviews of Big Tech mergers were too lax — such as when Facebook bought Instagram in 2012 and WhatsApp in 2014. In an...","isTpContent":false,"socialEmbeds":[],"isPrContent":false,"storyHTML":"\u003cp>Permanently misspelled tweets might soon be a thing of the past. \u003c/p>\u003cp>Twitter said Thursday it will roll out an editing feature to subscribers of its premium Twitter Blue service later this month. \u003c/p>\u003cp>In an update on its plans to introduce an edit button, the social media company said it has been testing the feature internally, which it said is one of the most requested features to date. \u003c/p>\u003cp>The edit function will give users 30 minutes to make changes to their 280-character messages such as fixing typos or adding hashtags after first publishing a tweet. \u003c/p>\u003cp>To make it clear that a tweet has been modified, they'll be labeled and appear with an icon and timestamp. Users can look up past versions of the tweet by tapping the label. \u003c/p>\u003cp>Twitter said it's testing the edit feature with a small group of users so it can identify and resolve potential issues. \u003c/p>\u003cp>“This includes how people might misuse the feature,” the company said in a blog post. “You can never be too careful.” \u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"ad-placeholder\" data='autoembed'>\u003c/div>\u003cp>The time limit and version history play an important role, Twitter said. “They help protect the integrity of the conversation and create a publicly accessible record of what was said.” \u003c/p>\u003cp>Twitter hinted that the edit feature would eventually be rolled out to all users. Testing helps the company understand how it impacts the way people use Twitter “as well as plan for and anticipate what might happen if we bring it to everyone,” spokeswoman Stephanie Cortez said. \u003c/p>\u003cdiv id='afs:Card:479163640945' class='hub-peek-embed' content-id='2f127fdbcb1928ab30008bdb62a48905'>Hub peek embed (TwitterInc) - Compressed layout (automatic embed) \u003c/div>\u003cp>Many Twitter users — among them, Kim Kardashian, Ice T, Katy Perry and McDonald’s corporate account — have long pleaded for an edit button. \u003c/p>\u003cp>The company \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/TwitterComms/status/1511456430024364037\">said in April\u003c/a> that it has been \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/technology-business-elon-musk-f3a99b8ab07f184f275a7f501e8f54b4\">working on the feature since last year\u003c/a>, a day after Tesla CEO \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/elonmusk/status/1511143607385874434\">Elon Musk polled his followers\u003c/a> on whether they wanted an edit button. About three-quarters of the 4.4 million respondents said yes. \u003c/p>\u003cp>Later that month, Musk offered to buy Twitter for $44 billion with the promise that his ownership would bring big changes to the service. He has since \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/elon-musk-twitter-inc-technology-4193a27d86458952542dfa2176150a01\">attempted to back out of the deal\u003c/a> citing concerns about fake accounts and whistleblower allegations of poor cybersecurity, setting the stage for a bruising legal battle over whether he has to go through with the purchase. \u003c/p>\u003cp>The premium service costs $4.99 per (AP video: Allen Breed, Haven Daley)","display":"se2","maxWidth":"","alignment":"middle","isHeroImage":false}],"isPrContent":false,"storyHTML":"\u003cp>Local law enforcement agencies from suburban Southern California to rural North Carolina have been using an obscure cellphone tracking tool, at times without search warrants, that gives them the power to follow people’s movements months back in time, according to public records and internal emails obtained by The Associated Press.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Police have used “Fog Reveal” to search hundreds of billions of records from 250 million mobile devices, and harnessed the data to create location analyses known among law enforcement as “patterns of life,” according to thousands of pages of records about the company.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Sold by Virginia-based Fog Data Science LLC, Fog Reveal has been used since at least 2018 in criminal investigations ranging from the murder of a nurse in Arkansas to tracing the movements of a potential participant in the Jan. 6 insurrection at the Capitol. The tool is rarely, if ever, mentioned in court records, something that defense attorneys say makes it harder for them to properly defend their clients in cases in which the technology was used.\u003c/p>\u003cdiv id=\"d81e1596289b4700854a42cd49c95aad\" class=\"media-placeholder\">\u003c/div>\u003cdiv id=\"559c0c23bc25478cbeea6d86b4206837\" class=\"media-placeholder\">\u003c/div>\u003cp>The company was developed by two former high-ranking Department of Homeland Security officials under former President George W. Bush. It relies on advertising identification numbers, which Fog officials say are culled from popular cellphone apps such as Waze, Starbucks and hundreds of others that target ads based on a person’s movements and interests, according to police emails. That information is then sold to companies like Fog.\u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"ad-placeholder\">\u003c/div>\u003cp>“It’s sort of a mass surveillance program on a budget,” said Bennett Cyphers, a special adviser at the Electronic Frontier Foundation, a digital privacy rights advocacy group.\u003c/p>\u003cp>_____\u003c/p>\u003cp>This story, supported by the Pulitzer Center for Crisis Reporting, is part of an ongoing Associated Press series, “Tracked,” that investigates the power and consequences of decisions driven by algorithms on people’s everyday lives.\u003c/p>\u003cdiv id=\"afs:Medium:583816932259\" class=\"media-placeholder\">\u003c/div>\u003cp>____\u003c/p>\u003cp>The documents and emails were obtained by EFF through Freedom of Information Act requests. The group shared the files with The AP, which independently found that Fog sold its software in about 40 contracts to nearly two dozen agencies, according to GovSpend, a company that keeps tabs on government spending. The records and AP’s reporting provide the first public account of the extensive use of Fog Reveal by local police, according to analysts and legal experts who scrutinize such technologies.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Federal oversight of companies like Fog is an evolving legal landscape. On Monday, the Federal Trade Commission sued a data broker called Kochava that, like Fog, provides its clients with advertising IDs that authorities say can easily be used to find where a mobile device user lives, which violates rules the commission enforces. And there are bills before Congress now that, if passed, would regulate the industry.\u003c/p>\u003cp>“Local law enforcement is at the front lines of trafficking and missing persons cases, yet these departments are often behind in technology adoption,” Matthew Broderick, a Fog managing partner, said in an email. “We fill a gap for underfunded and understaffed departments.”\u003c/p>\u003cp>Because of the secrecy surrounding Fog, however, there are scant details about its use and most law enforcement agencies won’t discuss it, raising concerns among privacy advocates that it violates the \u003ca href=\"https://www.uscourts.gov/about-federal-courts/educational-resources/about-educational-outreach/activity-resources/what-does-0#:~:text=The%20Constitution%2C%20through%20the%20Fourth,deemed%20unreasonable%20under%20the%20law.\">Fourth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution\u003c/a>, which protects against unreasonable search and seizure.\u003c/p>\u003cdiv id=\"26fd1ad5315f4fff990f685a772ed127\" class=\"media-placeholder\">\u003c/div>\u003cp>What distinguishes Fog Reveal from other cellphone location technologies used by police is that it follows the devices through their advertising IDs, unique numbers assigned to each device. These numbers do not contain the name of the phone’s user, but can be traced to homes and workplaces to help police establish pattern-of-life analyses.\u003c/p>\u003cp>“The capability that it had for bringing up just anybody in an area whether they were in public or at home seemed to me to be a very clear violation of the Fourth Amendment,” said Davin Hall, a former crime data analysis supervisor for the Greensboro, North Carolina, Police Department. “I just feel angry and betrayed and lied to.”\u003c/p>\u003cp>Hall resigned in late 2020 after months of voicing concerns about the department’s use of Fog to police attorneys and the city council. \u003c/p>\u003cdiv id=\"7b60c7e7fc1f448484e56aa728b0d4ed\" class=\"media-placeholder\">\u003c/div>\u003cp>While Greensboro officials acknowledged Fog’s use and initially defended it, the police department said it allowed its subscription to expire earlier this year because it didn’t “independently benefit investigations.”\u003c/p>\u003cp>But federal, state and local police agencies around the U.S. continue to use Fog with very little public accountability. Local police agencies have been enticed by Fog’s affordable price: It can start as low as $7,500 a year. And some departments that license it have shared access with other nearby law enforcement agencies, the emails show.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Police departments also like how quickly they can access detailed location information from Fog. Geofence warrants, which tap into GPS and other sources to track a device, are accessed by obtaining such data from companies, like Google or Apple. This requires police to obtain a warrant and ask the tech companies for the specific data they want, which can take days or weeks.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Using Fog’s data, which the company claims is anonymized, police can geofence an area or search by a specific device’s ad ID numbers, according to a user agreement obtained by AP. But, Fog maintains that \"we have no way of linking signals back to a specific device or owner,” according to a sales representative who emailed the California Highway Patrol in 2018, after a lieutenant asked whether the tool could be legally used.\u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"social-embed\" id=\"se2:effc5ae0-02f0-11ed-8ff5-d3ec7a905745\">\u003cdiv class=\"display-block\">\u003cstyle>@media only screen and (max-width: 415px){.htmlEmbedContent {width: 90%;margin: 0 auto;}}@media only screen and (min-width: 415px){.htmlEmbedContent {width: 70%;}}.youtube-container { position: relative; padding-bottom: 56.25%; height: 0; overflow: hidden; max-width: 100%; } .youtube-container iframe { position: absolute; top: 0; left: 0; width: 100%; height: 100%; }\u003c/style>\u003cdiv class=\"youtube-container\">\u003ciframe width=\"560\" height=\"315\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/qYfjWUxdkCc\" title=\"YouTube video player\" frameborder=\"0\" allow=\"accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture\" allowfullscreen>\u003c/iframe>\u003c/div>\u003c/div>\u003cp class=\"social-caption\">You might know that your cellphone has a unique code that allows advertisers to target you for promotions. What you may not know: That same number could be helping police surveil you without a warrant. (AP video: Allen Breed, Haven Daley)\u003c/p>\u003c/div>\u003cp>Despite such privacy assurances, the records show that law enforcement can use Fog’s data as a clue to find identifying information. “There is no (personal information) linked to the (ad ID),” wrote a Missouri official about Fog in 2019. “But if we are good at what we do, we should be able to figure out the owner.”\u003c/p>\u003cp>Fog’s Broderick said in an email that the company does not have access to people’s personal information, and draws from “commercially available data without restrictions to use,” from data brokers \"that legitimately purchase data from apps in accordance with their legal agreements.” The company refused to share information about how many police agencies it works with.\u003c/p>\u003cp>“We are confident Law Enforcement has the responsible leadership, constraints, and political guidance at the municipal, state, and federal level to ensure that any law enforcement tool and method is appropriately used in accordance with the laws in their respective jurisdictions,” Broderick said.\u003c/p>\u003cp>___\u003c/p>\u003cp>Kevin Metcalf, a prosecutor in Washington County, Arkansas, said he has used Fog Reveal without a warrant, especially in “exigent circumstances.” In these cases, the law provides a warrant exemption when a crime-in-process endangers people or an officer. \u003c/p>\u003cp>Metcalf also leads the National Child Protection Task Force, a nonprofit that combats child exploitation and trafficking. Fog \u003ca href=\"https://www.ncptf.org/team\">is listed on its website\u003c/a> as a task force sponsor and a company executive chairs the nonprofit’s board. Metcalf said Fog has been invaluable to cracking missing children cases and homicides.\u003c/p>\u003cp>“We push the limits, but we do them in a way that we target the bad guys,” he said. “Time is of the essence in those situations. We can’t wait on the traditional search warrant route.”\u003c/p>\u003cp>Fog was used successfully in the murder case of 25-year-old nurse Sydney Sutherland, who had last been seen jogging near Newport, Arkansas, before she disappeared, Metcalf said.\u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"ad-placeholder\">\u003c/div>\u003cp>Police had little evidence to go on when they found her phone in a ditch, so Metcalf said he shared his agency’s access to Fog with the U.S. Marshals Service to figure out which other devices had been nearby at the time she was killed. He said Fog helped lead authorities to arrest a farmer in Sutherland’s rape and murder in August 2020, but its use was not documented in court records reviewed by AP.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Cyphers, who led EFF’s public records work, said there hasn’t been any previous record of companies selling this kind of granular data directly to local law enforcement.\u003c/p>\u003cp>“We’re seeing counties with less than 100,000 people where the sheriff is using this extremely high tech, extremely invasive, secretive surveillance tool to chase down local crime,” Cyphers said.\u003c/p>\u003cdiv id=\"45d5e3941cf24040a50d9e16e2b1efd2\" class=\"media-placeholder\">\u003c/div>\u003cp>One such customer is the sheriff’s office in rural Rockingham County, North Carolina, population 91,000 and just north of Greensboro, where Hall still lives. The county bought a one-year license for $9,000 last year and recently renewed it.\u003c/p>\u003cp>“Rockingham County is tiny in terms of population. It never ceases to amaze me how small agencies will scoop up tools that they just absolutely don’t need, and nobody needs this one,” Hall said.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Sheriff’s spokesman Lt. Kevin Suthard confirmed the department recently renewed its license but declined to offer specifics about the use of Fog Reveal or how the office protects individuals’ rights. \u003c/p>\u003cp>“Because it would then be less effective as criminals could be cognizant that we have the device and adjust their commission of the crimes accordingly. Make sense?” Suthard said.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Fog has aggressively marketed its tool to police, even beta testing it with law enforcement, records show. The Dallas Police Department bought a Fog license in February after getting a free trial and “seeing a demonstration and hearing of success stories from the company,” Senior Cpl. Melinda Gutierrez, a department spokeswoman, said in an email.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Fog’s tool is accessed through a web portal. Investigators can enter a crime scene’s coordinates into the database, which brings back search results showing a device’s Fog ID, which is based on its unique ad ID number.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Police can see which device IDs were found near the location of the crime. Detectives or other officers can also search the location for IDs going forward from the time of the crime and back at least 180 days, according to the company’s user license agreement. But, Fog’s data can go back as far as June 2017, according to emails from a Fog representative to Florida and California law enforcement agencies.\u003c/p>\u003cp>While the data does not directly identify who owns a device, the company often gives law enforcement information it needs to connect it to addresses and other clues that help detectives figure out people’s identities, according to company representatives’ emails.\u003c/p>\u003cp>It is unclear how Fog makes these connections, but a company it refers to as its “data partner” called Venntel, Inc. has access to an even greater trove of users’ mobile data.\u003c/p>\u003cdiv id=\"8e5da4199fbe441a8167ed1b8770d124\" class=\"media-placeholder\">\u003c/div>\u003cp>Venntel is a large broker that has supplied location data to agencies such as Immigration and Customs Enforcement and the FBI. The Department of Homeland Security’s watchdog is currently investigating how U.S. border agents used Venntel data to track people’s locations inside the U.S. without a search warrant. The company also has faced congressional inquiries about privacy concerns tied to federal law enforcement agencies’ use of its data.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Venntel and Fog work closely together to aid police detectives during investigations, emails show. Their marketing brochures are nearly identical, too, and Venntel staff has recommended Fog to law enforcement, according to the emails. Venntel said “the confidential nature of our business relationships” prevented it from responding to AP’s specific questions, and Fog would not comment on the relationship.\u003c/p>\u003cp>While Fog says in its marketing materials that it collects data from thousands of apps, like Starbucks and Waze, companies are not always aware of who is using their data. Venntel and Fog can collect billions of data points filled with detailed information because many apps embed invisible tracking software that follows users’ behavior. This software also lets the apps sell customized ads that are targeted to a person’s current location. In turn, data brokers’ software can hoover up personal data that can be used for other purposes. Fog did not specifically say how it got the data from Starbucks and Waze.\u003c/p>\u003cp>For their part, Starbucks and Waze denied any relationship to Fog. Starbucks said it had not given permission to its business partners to share customer information with Fog.\u003c/p>\u003cp>“Starbucks has not approved Ad ID data generated by our app to be used in this way by Fog Data Science LLC. In our review to date, we have no relationship with this company,” said Megan Adams, a Starbucks spokesperson.\u003c/p>\u003cp>“We have never had a relationship with Fog Data Science, have not worked with them in any capacity, and have not shared information with them,” a Waze spokesperson said.\u003c/p>\u003cp>___\u003c/p>\u003cp>Fog Data Science LLC is headquartered in a nondescript brick building in Leesburg, Virginia. It also has related entities in New Jersey, Ohio and Texas.\u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"ad-placeholder\">\u003c/div>\u003cp>It was founded in 2016 by Robert Liscouski, who led the Department of Homeland Security’s National Cyber Security Division in the George W. Bush adminstration. His colleague, Broderick, is a former U.S. Marine brigadier general who ran DHS’ tech hub, the Homeland Security Operations Center, during Hurricane Katrina in 2005. A House bipartisan committee report cited Broderick among others for failing to coordinate a swift federal response to the deadly hurricane. Broderick resigned from DHS shortly thereafter.\u003c/p>\u003cp>In marketing materials, Fog also has touted its ability to offer police “predictive analytics,” a buzzword often used to describe high-tech policing tools that purport to predict crime hotspots. Liscouski and another Fog official have worked at companies focused on predictive analytics, machine learning and software platforms supporting artificial intelligence.\u003c/p>\u003cp>“It is capable of delivering both forensic and predictive analytics and near real-time insights on the daily movements of the people identified with those mobile devices,” reads an email announcing a Fog training last year for members of the National Fusion Center Association, which represents a network of intelligence-sharing partnerships created after the Sept. 11 attacks.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Fog’s Broderick said the company had not invested in predictive applications, and provided no details about any uses the tool had for predicting crime.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Despite privacy advocates’ concerns about warrantless surveillance, Fog Reveal has caught on with local and state police forces. It’s been used in a number of high-profile criminal cases, including one that was the subject of the television program “48 Hours.”\u003c/p>\u003cdiv id=\"afs:Card:197563501016\" content-id=\"d395409ef5a8c6c3f6cdab5b1d0e27ef\" class=\"hub-peek-embed\">Hub peek embed (apf-technology) - Compressed layout\u003c/div>\u003cp>In 2017, a world-renowned exotic snake breeder was found dead, lying in a pool of blood in his reptile breeding facility in rural Missouri. Police initially thought the breeder, Ben Renick, might have died from a poisonous snake bite. But the evidence soon pointed to murder.\u003c/p>\u003cp>During its investigation, emails show the Missouri State Highway Patrol used Fog’s portal to search for cellphones at Renick’s home and breeding facility and zeroed in on a mobile device. Working with Fog, investigators used the data to identify the phone owner’s identity: it was the Renicks’ babysitter.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Police were able to log the babysitter’s whereabouts over time to create a pattern of life analysis. \u003c/p>\u003cp>It turned out to be a dead-end lead. Renick’s wife, Lynlee, later was charged and convicted of the murder.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Prosecutors did not cite Fog in a list of other tools they used in the investigation, according to trial exhibits examined by the AP. \u003c/p>\u003cp>But Missouri officials seemed pleased with Fog’s capabilities, even though it didn’t directly lead to an arrest. “It was interesting to see that the system did pick up a device that was absolutely in the area that day. Too bad it did not belong to a suspect!” a Missouri State Highway Patrol analyst wrote in an email to Fog.\u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"ad-placeholder\">\u003c/div>\u003cp>In another high-profile criminal probe, records show the FBI asked state intelligence officials in Iowa for help with Fog as it investigated potential participants in the events at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6.\u003c/p>\u003cp>“Not definitive but still waiting to talk things over with a FOG rep,” wrote Justin Parker, deputy director of the Iowa Department of Public Safety, in an email to an FBI official in September 2021. It was unclear from the emails if Fog’s data factored into an arrest, and neither the FBI nor Iowa officials would comment.\u003c/p>\u003cp>___\u003c/p>\u003cp>Metcalf, the Arkansas prosecutor, has argued against congressional efforts to require search warrants when using technologies like Fog Reveal.\u003c/p>\u003cp>He believes Americans have given up any reasonable expectation of privacy when they use free apps and likens EFF’s objections to tech like Fog to a “cult of privacy.”\u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"ad-placeholder\">\u003c/div>\u003cp>“I think people are going to have to make a decision on whether we want all this free technology, we want all this free stuff, we want all the selfies,” he said. “But we can’t have that and at the same time say, ‘I’m a private person, so you can’t look at any of that.’ That just seems crazy.”\u003c/p>\u003cp>Although he is not an official Fog employee, Metcalf said he would step in to lead training sessions including the tool for federal prosecutors, federal agencies and police, including the Chicago Police Department, the emails show.\u003c/p>\u003cp>That kind of hands-on service and word-of-mouth marketing in tight-knit law enforcement circles seems to have helped increase Fog’s popularity.\u003c/p>\u003cp>The Maryland State Police is among the many agencies that have had contracts for Fog Reveal, and records show investigators believed it had a lot of potential.\u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"social-embed\" id=\"se1:70ba9330-02f0-11ed-d109-9f09bc703a39\">\u003cdiv style=\"padding:56.25% 0 0 0;position:relative;\">\u003ciframe src=\"https://player.vimeo.com/video/744726603?background=1\" title=0&byline=0&portrait=0\" style=\"position:absolute;top:0;left:0;width:100%;height:100%;\" frameborder=\"0\" webkitallowfullscreen mozallowfullscreen allowfullscreen>\u003c/iframe>\u003c/div>\u003cscript src=\"https://player.vimeo.com/api/player.js\">\u003c/script>\u003cp class=\"social-caption\">A cell phone tower in Raleigh, North Carolina\u003c/p>\u003c/div>\u003cp>“Companies have receptors all over. Malls, shopping centers, etc. They’re all around you,” wrote Sgt. John Bedell of the Criminal Enforcement Division, in an email to a colleague. The agency purchased a year of access to Fog in 2018.\u003c/p>\u003cp>“Picture getting a suspect’s phone then in the extraction being able to see everyplace they’d been in the last 18 months plotted on a map you filter by date ranges,” wrote Bedell. “The success lies in the secrecy.” \u003c/p>\u003cp>Elena Russo, a spokesperson for the agency, confirmed it had a Fog license previously but that it had lapsed. “Unfortunately, it was not helpful in solving any crimes,” she wrote in an email.\u003c/p>\u003cdiv class=\"ad-placeholder\">\u003c/div>\u003cp>Still, as more local policing agencies sign up for Fog, some elected officials said they have been left in the dark. Several officials said there wasn’t enough information to grasp what services Fog actually provides.\u003c/p>\u003cp>“Who is this company? What are the track records? What are the privacy protections?” asked Anaheim council member Jose Moreno, remembering his confusion about Fog during a 2020 council meeting. “That night our chief had very little information for us.”\u003c/p>\u003cp>In Anaheim, the Fog license was paid for by a federal “Urban Area Security Initiative,” DHS grants that help localities fund efforts to prevent terrorism. A police spokesman said the department has not used it. \u003c/p>\u003cp>Defense attorneys worry there are few legal restrictions on law enforcement’s use of location data.\u003c/p>\u003cp>It’s a gap police agencies exploit, and often don’t disclose in court, said Michael Price, litigation director of the National Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers’ Fourth Amendment Center.\u003c/p>\u003cp>“(Fog) is exceedingly rare to see in the wild because the cops often don’t get warrants,” said Price.\u003c/p>\u003cp>“Even if you do ask for (information) sometimes they say ‘We don’t know what you are talking about.’”\u003c/p>\u003cp>Privacy advocates worry Fog’s location tracking could be put to other novel uses, like keeping tabs on people who seek abortions in states where it is now illegal. These concerns were heightened when \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/abortion-health-nebraska-government-and-politics-b94abeeed9a8c486cf479d6ae78c62aa\">a Nebraska woman was charged in August\u003c/a> with helping her teenage daughter end a pregnancy after investigators got hold of their Facebook messages.\u003c/p>\u003cdiv id=\"b4d36c88f96444fa8a82ebdcb79a6001\" class=\"media-placeholder\">\u003c/div>\u003cp>Government’s use of location data is still being weighed by the courts, too. In 2018, the Supreme Court ruled that police generally need a warrant to look at records that reveal where cellphone users have been.\u003c/p>\u003cp>Nearly two years after walking off the crime data supervisor job with the Greensboro police force, Hall still worries about police surveillance in neighboring communities.\u003c/p>\u003cp>“Anyone with that login information can do as many searches as they want,” Hall said. “I don’t believe the police have earned the trust to use that, and I don’t believe it should be legal.”\u003c/p>\u003cp>___\u003c/p>\u003cp>AP National Writer Allen G. Breed contributed from Greensboro, North Carolina.
